body_html:
Enabling tracing is expensive, so you don't want to turn it on for every step, just use it for sampling.
To export it, you export it like any protocol buffer - save the serialized version to a file/string and then load that up in Python using something like:

from tensorflow.core.framework.step_stats_pb2 import StepStats

step_stats = StepStats()
step_stats.ParseFromString(<the serialized form of the proto from C++>)

Hope that helps.
body_text:
Enabling tracing is expensive, so you don't want to turn it on for every step, just use it for sampling.
To export it, you export it like any protocol buffer - save the serialized version to a file/string and then load that up in Python using something like:
from tensorflow.core.framework.step_stats_pb2 import StepStats

step_stats = StepStats()
step_stats.ParseFromString(<the serialized form of the proto from C++>)
Hope that helps.
body:
Enabling tracing is expensive, so you don't want to turn it on for every step, just use it for sampling.
To export it, you export it like any protocol buffer - save the serialized version to a file/string and then load that up in Python using something like:

```python
from tensorflow.core.framework.step_stats_pb2 import StepStats

step_stats = StepStats()
step_stats.ParseFromString(<the serialized form of the proto from C++>)
```

Hope that helps.
